page.title: 09FARMING IN FYLINGDALES
page.content: SHEEP. The different breeds of sheep around here are: Swaledale, Suffolk, Masham and Jacob. You would usually find Swaledales on the moor because they are a hardy breed. You would not find many old sheep there because they lose their teeth and cannot eat heather. The farmer then brings them inside and feeds them on rolled barley and concentrate pellets or sends them to be slaughtered. Jacobs are black and white. They are kept for the wool used in knitting. They have two pairs of horns, a long and a short pair. Suffolks have a black face and legs. They are kept in fields where the farmers can see them because they are not very tough and need to be cared for and fed in winter.
